div.l: Abowte Myddnyghte wente they to reste
Wele haþe this Myller varneschede his hede
Fulle pale he was Fordrunken ⁊and notte rede
He yexeþe And spekeþe þroughe his nose
As he were on the qwacke or on þe pose
To bedde he gothe And with hym gothe his wyfe
As enye Iaye he lyghte was And Iolyfe
So was her Iolye whystille welle ywette
The Cradulle Atte þe beddes Fete is sette
To rokken And to yeuen the childe Souke
And whan þat drunken was All in the crouke
To bedde wente the doughter righte Anone
To bedde gothe Aleyn and allso Iohn
There nas nomore þem nedede no dwale
This Myller haþe so wyselye bybbede Ale
That as An horse he Snorteþe in his slepe
Ne of his tayle behynde toke he no kepe
Her hisHer His wyfe bare hym A burdon A Fulle stronge
Men myghten here rowtynge þ̉er A Furlonge
The wenche rowteþe eke ꝑpar Companye
Aleyn the Clarke þat harde this Mellodye
He powkede Iohn And sayde Slepeste thou
Hardeste þou eủer Suche a songe As now
Loo Suche A couplenge is bitwyxe hem all
A wylde Fuyer on thayre bodyes Falle
Who harde eủer suche A Ferlye þynge
Ye they schall haue the Flowre of euelle endenge
This longe nyghte þ̉ere tydes Men no reste
Butte yett no Force All schall be For the beste
For Aleyn sayde so eủer Motte I thryue
Yefe þat I maye yonder wenche woll I swyue
Some esement hathe lawe Schapen vs
